thread.title: Man who killed Joe McKnight acted in self defense: attorneys
thread.title_full: Man who killed Joe McKnight acted in self defense: attorneys

author: ANDY CLAYTON
title: Man who killed Joe McKnight acted in self defense: attorneys

organizations.name: sports stars gone too soon  when

text:
NEW YORK DAILY NEWS  21 PM 
The man who shot and killed Joe McKnight acted in self defense, his legal team told The Associated Press. 
Ronald Gasser, 55, was i ndicted Wednesday on a second-degree murder charge in the December road rage incident that ended with the former Jets running back dead in the New Orleans suburb of Terrytown. 
"Mr. Gasser did what he is legally entitled to do and defended himself," his attorneys Matthew Goetz and Gerard Archer wrote in an email to the AP on Thursday night. "Mr. Gasser did not know Mr. McKnight nor was this in any way racially motivated. He feared for his safety and acted." 
Gasser is being held on $750,000 bond. The charge carries a mandatory life sentence if convicted. Ex-Jets RB Joe McKnight was shot and killed in a December road rage incident in a New Orleans suburb. (Uncredited/AP) 
"Information provided from our sources indicates that McKnight exited his vehicle and attempted to enter through the passenger window of Mr. Gasser's vehicle while threatening him with serious bodily harm," the two attorneys wrote. 
Gasser, who was released by Jefferson Parish police to much public outrage after being initial questioning after the Dec. 1 shooting, was then arrested and charged with manslaughter five days later. 
After shooting the former Louisiana prep standout, Gasser stayed on the scene and confessed when cops arrived on the scene. Ronald Gasser is being held on $750,000 bond after being charged with second-degree murder. (Jefferson Parish Sheriff's Office) 
"(Gasser) did what is expected of people who are following the law," the lawyers' email continued. "He waited for the police and cooperated fully with the investigation." 
Antonio Cromartie, other ex-Jets attend funeral of Joe McKnight 
The incident began as both drivers were driving erratically and yelling at each other as they crossed a bridge from New Orleans into Terrytown, authorities said. 
"It is our understanding (which can be verified by a simple viewing of the photos of the scene following the incident) that Mr. McKnight drove his vehicle from several car lengths behind Mr. Gasser and then pulled over onto the shoulder of the road trapping Mr. Gasser's vehicle," the lawyers' email continued. Sports Stars Gone Too Soon 
When asked Thursday by the AP if McKnight had reached into Gasser's car, Jefferson Parish Sheriff Newell Normand passed the decision to release details to the DA in the case. 
"I'm not here to compromise our case and I'm not here to argue our case," Normand told the AP. "The district attorney ... alone will decide when he wants to reveal certain aspects of this case." 
Follow the Daily News Sports on Facebook. "Like" us here. 
McKnight, 28, was a fourth round pick by the Jets in the 2010 NFL Draft after three seasons at USC. He rushed for 502 yards and had two kickoff returns for touchdowns during his three-year stint with Gang Green. He played one season with the Chiefs before played in the CFL. 
With The Associated Press
